slides.text: A QUADRILATERAL is any polygon with 4 sides. Just as triangle angles sum to 180°, quadrilateral angles sum to 360° (because any quadrilateral can be divided into 2 triangles: 2 × 180° = 360°). Draw any quadrilateral, measure all 4 angles, and verify they sum to 360°.

The quadrilateral family: PARALLELOGRAM — opposite sides parallel and equal. RECTANGLE — parallelogram with 4 right angles. RHOMBUS — parallelogram with 4 equal sides. SQUARE — rectangle AND rhombus: 4 equal sides AND 4 right angles. TRAPEZOID — exactly one pair of parallel sides. KITE — two pairs of consecutive equal sides.

The hierarchy (this is important!): Every SQUARE is a RECTANGLE (it has 4 right angles). Every SQUARE is a RHOMBUS (it has 4 equal sides). Every RECTANGLE is a PARALLELOGRAM. Every RHOMBUS is a PARALLELOGRAM. But NOT every rectangle is a square, and NOT every parallelogram is a rectangle. Draw this as a flow chart.

Properties to check: PARALLEL SIDES (use a ruler to check if sides would never meet). RIGHT ANGLES (use the protractor or a corner of paper). EQUAL SIDES (measure with a ruler). EQUAL DIAGONALS (draw the diagonals and measure). These properties determine the classification.

slides.prompt: Complete these tasks: (1) Draw one example of each: parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, square, trapezoid, kite. Label all sides and angles. (2) Create a Venn diagram or hierarchy chart showing relationships (which types contain which other types). (3) True or false (explain each): a) Every square is a rhombus. b) Every rhombus is a square. c) Every rectangle is a parallelogram. d) Every trapezoid is a parallelogram. (4) Find the missing angle: a quadrilateral has angles 90°, 90°, 110°, ?. (5) Hunt for quadrilaterals in your room — classify each one.

slides.text: Quadrilaterals are everywhere in human design — windows, doors, screens, books, tables, tiles. Understanding their properties helps in architecture, engineering, art, and beyond. The hierarchy of quadrilaterals teaches an important mathematical concept: classification based on properties.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student classify quadrilaterals by their properties, understand the hierarchy of relationships, and apply the 360° angle sum property?

parent_notes: The quadrilateral hierarchy is a concept that challenges many students (and adults!). The key insight is that classification is based on PROPERTIES: a square has all the properties of a rectangle (4 right angles) AND all the properties of a rhombus (4 equal sides), so it belongs to both categories. The Venn diagram or hierarchy chart is a valuable reference. Connect to the real world: look for different quadrilaterals in your home, in architecture, and in nature (crystals). The castle architecture from the art lesson provides many examples.

title: Knights and Chivalry — Training, Armor, and the Code of Honor
description: Students learn about the training, equipment, and code of honor of medieval knights. They explore the path from page to squire to knight, study medieval armor and weapons, and analyze the code of chivalry as both an ideal and a reality.
instructions:
1. The path to knighthood: page (age 7), squire (age 14), knight (age 21).
2. Training: horsemanship, swordsmanship, jousting, courtesy, reading, music.
3. The dubbing ceremony: vigil, oath, accolade.
4. Arms and armor: chainmail to plate armor, swords, lances, shields.
5. The code of chivalry: courage, loyalty, honor, courtesy, protection of the weak.
6. Discuss: How well did knights actually follow the code? Ideal vs. reality.
7. Heraldry connection: identifying knights in battle.
8. Students create a 'Knight's Handbook' summarizing the path, equipment, and code.
materials_needed: Reference images of armor and weapons

items: Your coat of arms from week 10
slides.setup_instructions: Open history notebook. Find your coat of arms from week 10 for reference. Look up images of medieval knights and armor.

slides.text: Becoming a knight was a 14-year process: PAGE (age 7-14) — a boy left home to serve in a lord's household, learning manners, reading, music, and beginning physical training. SQUIRE (age 14-21) — he served a specific knight, caring for armor and horses, learning combat, and fighting alongside his knight. KNIGHT (age 21) — after proving himself, he was 'dubbed' in a ceremony.

The dubbing ceremony: The night before, the squire kept a vigil (stayed awake all night in a chapel, praying and reflecting). At dawn, he bathed (symbolizing purification), dressed in white (purity), red (willingness to shed blood), and black (preparedness for death). He knelt before his lord, swore an oath, and was tapped on the shoulder with a sword — 'I dub thee knight.'

Medieval armor evolved: CHAINMAIL (linked metal rings, flexible but heavy) → PLATE ARMOR (solid metal pieces, better protection, very heavy — a full suit weighed 45-55 pounds). Weapons: SWORD (the knight's primary weapon and symbol), LANCE (for jousting and cavalry charges), SHIELD (protection and identity through heraldry), MACE (for crushing armor).

The code of chivalry idealized: VALOR (courage in battle), LOYALTY (to one's lord), HONOR (keeping promises), COURTESY (especially to women and elders), PROTECTION (defending the weak and the Church), GENEROSITY (to the poor). Reality check: many knights fell short. They could be brutal, greedy, and oppressive. Chivalry was an IDEAL, not always a practice.

slides.prompt: Create a 'Knight's Handbook' in your notebook: (1) A timeline showing the path from page to squire to knight with key milestones. (2) A labeled diagram of a knight in full armor (label at least 8 pieces of equipment). (3) The Code of Chivalry written in formal, medieval-style language. (4) A paragraph answering: Was the code of chivalry a genuine moral standard or just a nice story? Give evidence for your answer. (5) How does your coat of arms from week 10 connect to knightly identity?

slides.text: The knight is one of history's most romanticized figures. The reality was more complex than the legend — knights were both protectors and aggressors, honorable and brutal. Understanding this complexity teaches us that history is never as simple as heroes and villains.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the path to knighthood, identify key equipment and the code of chivalry, and critically evaluate the gap between chivalric ideals and reality?

parent_notes: Knights fascinate children, making this an engaging lesson. The critical thinking component — was chivalry real or idealized? — is important for developing mature historical thinking. Help your child see that romantic portrayals of knights (in movies and games) often gloss over the violence and inequality of the feudal system. The dubbing ceremony is dramatic and memorable. The armor weight detail (45-55 pounds) can be made tangible — have your child wear a heavy backpack to feel what movement in armor was like. This lesson connects to the coat of arms art project and the feudalism history lesson.

title: Vertebrate Animals — Birds and Mammals
description: Students complete the vertebrate survey by studying the two warm-blooded classes: birds and mammals. They explore the adaptations that enable flight and thermoregulation, and compare all five vertebrate classes in a comprehensive summary.
instructions:
1. Review fish, amphibians, and reptiles from Day 4.
2. Birds: feathers, hollow bones, beaks, warm-blooded, lay hard-shelled eggs, most fly.
3. Discuss adaptations for flight: lightweight bones, efficient lungs, strong chest muscles.
4. Mammals: fur/hair, mammary glands (milk), warm-blooded, most give live birth.
5. Discuss the diversity of mammals: land, sea, air (bats), egg-laying (monotremes).
6. The key innovation: being warm-blooded — why it matters.
7. Create comprehensive comparison of all 5 vertebrate classes.
8. Discuss: Which class is most successful? How do you define success?

slides.setup_instructions: Open science notebook. Add two more pages to your vertebrate series. Have colored pencils ready for illustrations.

slides.text: BIRDS: Over 10,000 species, found on every continent. Key features: FEATHERS (unique to birds — for flight, insulation, and display), HOLLOW BONES (lightweight for flight), BEAK instead of teeth (lighter), WARM-BLOODED (maintain constant body temperature), lay HARD-SHELLED EGGS, have a highly efficient respiratory system with air sacs.

How do birds fly? The combination of: (1) Lightweight hollow bones. (2) Powerful chest muscles (the breast muscles can be 25% of body weight). (3) Wing shape creates LIFT (same principle as airplane wings). (4) Feathers provide surface area and control. Not all birds fly — penguins swim, ostriches run. Flight is an adaptation, not a requirement for being a bird.

MAMMALS: About 6,400 species. Key features: HAIR or FUR (for insulation), MAMMARY GLANDS (produce milk to feed young), WARM-BLOODED, most give LIVE BIRTH (except monotremes: platypus, echidna), larger brain relative to body size than other vertebrates. Mammals live everywhere: land (elephants), sea (whales), air (bats), underground (moles).

Why is being WARM-BLOODED (endothermic) important? It means you can be active in any temperature. Cold-blooded animals slow down in cold weather — a lizard on a cold morning cannot run from predators. Warm-blooded animals can hunt, flee, and function in any conditions. The cost: we need MUCH more food (about 10x more than a same-sized reptile) to fuel our internal furnace.

slides.prompt: Create a MASTER COMPARISON CHART of all 5 vertebrate classes with these columns: Class, Body Covering, Breathing, Temperature, Reproduction, Habitat, Number of Species, Example. Then answer: (1) Which class has the most species? (2) Which class are humans in? List 5 characteristics that prove it. (3) Is a penguin a bird or a mammal? How do you know? (4) Is a whale a fish or a mammal? Explain. (5) Which vertebrate class do you think is most 'successful' and why?

slides.text: From fish to mammals, vertebrates represent over 500 million years of evolution. Each class developed adaptations for its environment — gills for water, lungs for air, feathers for flight, fur for warmth. Understanding these relationships helps us see the unity and diversity of life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe key characteristics of all 5 vertebrate classes and compare them across multiple categories?

parent_notes: This lesson completes the vertebrate survey. The master comparison chart is a valuable reference for the rest of the biology unit. The tricky classification questions (Is a penguin a bird? Is a whale a mammal?) teach children to classify based on CHARACTERISTICS rather than superficial appearance. The 'which class is most successful' question has no right answer but sparks excellent critical thinking. If you have pets, identify their class and discuss their specific adaptations. Bird watching is a wonderful extension activity that combines science and outdoor time.

title: Tapestry Art — The Bayeux Tapestry and Visual Storytelling
description: Students study the Bayeux Tapestry as an example of medieval visual storytelling, learn about the craft of tapestry making, and create their own narrative tapestry strip telling a story from history or their own life.
instructions:
1. Introduce the Bayeux Tapestry: 230 feet long, tells the story of the Norman Conquest (1066).
2. Examine sections: how the story unfolds in sequential panels.
3. Discuss tapestry as a medium: embroidery on linen, years to create.
4. Analyze the visual storytelling techniques: figures, borders, Latin text.
5. Students choose a story to tell in tapestry form.
6. Create a long narrative strip with sequential scenes.
7. Add borders with decorative elements.
8. Present the tapestry, narrating the story it tells.
materials_needed: Long strip of paper (or taped sheets)

slides.heading: Tapestry Art
slides.subheading: The Bayeux Tapestry and Visual Storytelling

items: Long paper strip (tape sheets together for at least 3 feet)
slides.setup_instructions: Tape several sheets of paper together to create a long strip at least 3 feet long and about 8 inches tall. Look up images of the Bayeux Tapestry online.

slides.text: The Bayeux Tapestry is one of the world's greatest works of narrative art. Created around 1070 CE, it is actually an embroidery (not a woven tapestry) on linen cloth, measuring 230 feet long and 20 inches tall. It tells the story of the Norman Conquest of England in 1066 through 58 scenes, like a medieval comic strip.

Study how it works: figures are shown in profile (side view), arranged left to right in chronological order. A top border and bottom border feature animals, symbols, and scenes of daily life. Brief Latin text identifies key characters and events. The flat, stylized figures convey action clearly even from a distance.

Choose your story. It can be: (a) A historical event you have studied (the Fall of Rome, a Viking voyage, the building of a castle). (b) A personal narrative (your family's story, a memorable trip, a year of your life). (c) A retelling of a story you love. Plan at least 6 sequential scenes.

Create your tapestry: (1) Divide your strip into panels with pencil lines. (2) Sketch figures in a flat, medieval style (profile views, simple shapes). (3) Add a decorative top and bottom border. (4) Add brief text labels for each scene. (5) Color with flat, bold colors (medieval tapestries used limited palettes: blues, reds, greens, yellows, black).

slides.prompt: Complete your narrative tapestry strip. Include: at least 6 sequential scenes, figures in medieval flat style, decorative borders above and below, text labels identifying scenes, and consistent color scheme. When finished, display the tapestry and narrate the story to someone, pointing to each scene as you tell it — just as a medieval storyteller might have done.

slides.text: The Bayeux Tapestry has survived nearly 1,000 years and is still telling its story. Your tapestry tells YOUR story. Visual storytelling — telling stories through images — predates writing and continues today in comics, graphic novels, and film. You are part of an ancient tradition.
slides.mastery_check: Did the student create a narrative tapestry strip with sequential scenes, medieval-inspired artistic style, and clear visual storytelling?

parent_notes: The Bayeux Tapestry is a masterpiece of narrative art and an important historical document. Looking at it online is essential for this project. The tapestry-making process connects art, history, and storytelling. Children love the comic-strip-like format. The presentation component (narrating while pointing) is a public speaking exercise. If your child enjoys this, the tapestry can be extended over time to tell more of the story. The project can also be done with fabric and embroidery for a more authentic experience.
